sections.title: ROTATION OF THE EARTH
sections.content_md:
**Rotation** is the spinning of the earth on its axis from west to east once in 24 hours. The **axis** is the imaginary line passing through the centre of the earth. The two end points through which the axis passes are known as the **North Pole** and the **South Pole**.

The axis is tilted at an angle of 23½° from the vertical. This means that if a line were drawn parallel to the plane of the earth's orbit, the axis would make an angle of 66½° to this line.

[Image: Fig. 3.1. Inclination of the earth's axis]

sections.title: Direction
sections.content_md: The earth completes one rotation from west to east on its axis in 23 hours, 56 minutes, 4.09 seconds (roughly in 24 hours).

sections.title: Inclination of Axis
sections.content_md: The earth is always tilted in the same direction (towards the Pole Star) as it moves round the sun. The angle at which the earth is tilted is known as the **inclination of the earth's axis**.

sections.title: Speed
sections.content_md: The speed of earth's rotation at the Equator is **1670 km per hour** (circumference of the earth is 40,075 km, which is covered in 24 hours). The speed decreases towards the poles.

sections.title: Effects of the Rotation of the Earth
Occurrence of Day and Night
sections.content_md:
Day and Night are caused by the rotation of the earth on its axis. Parts of the earth which face the sun have **day** and the parts which do not face the sun have **night**. This happens with precision and progression, not suddenly.

*   **Dawn**: The time when the sun begins to cast its light in the sky.
*   **Noon**: The sun is overhead.
*   **Dusk/Twilight**: The time when the sun is seen disappearing in the sky.

The duration of day and night is not equal at all places on the earth because of the inclined axis. The length of days varies with respect to the seasons as well as latitude.

sections.title: Sunrise and Sunset
sections.content_md: **Sunrise** and **Sunset** are caused by the rotation of the earth from west to east. As every part of the earth's surface faces the sun at some time, the part that moves from darkness into the sun's rays experiences sunrise, and when it moves away from the sun's rays, it experiences sunset.

sections.title: Coriolis Effect
sections.content_md:
**Coriolis Effect** refers to the force experienced by any object moving over the surface of a rotating body such as the earth. It plays an important role in the movement of air (winds) and water (ocean currents). Due to its effect:

*   In the **Northern Hemisphere**, winds and ocean currents move clockwise and are deflected to the right.
*   In the **Southern Hemisphere**, they move in the anticlockwise direction and are deflected to the left.

sections.title: The sun, the moon and the stars seem to move from east to west
sections.content_md: This apparent movement is because the earth spins from west to east. This effect is similar to what one experiences while looking at trees from a moving train.

sections.title: Centrifugal force
sections.content_md: **Centrifugal force** is an apparent outward force that acts on a rotating object, directed away from the axis of rotation. The speed of rotation has created a centrifugal force resulting in a bulge in the middle portion of the earth and a flattened top at the poles.

sections.title: Rotation causes difference in time over various places on the earth
sections.content_md: The difference in time is 4 minutes for each degree of longitude [24 hours (1440 minutes) divided by 360°].

sections.title: The side of the earth towards the sun constantly gains heat and the side away from the sun constantly loses heat by radiating it into outer space
sections.content_md: In this respect, rotation of the earth in a tilted position on its axis has the following advantages:

sections.title: The short rotational period makes the variation of temperature between day and night moderate.
Rotation in combination with Revolution (earth's movement round the sun) causes seasons and variations in the lengths of day and night over different places on earth.
INCLINATION OF EARTH'S AXIS AND ITS SIGNIFICANCE
sections.content_md:
The earth's axis is not vertical. It makes an angle of **23½°** with the vertical or **66½°** with the plane of the Earth's orbit. If the earth had a vertical axis, then at all places on the earth, the length of day and night would have been equal.

[Image: Fig. 3.2. Hypothetical Vertical Axis]

sections.title: Effect of the Inclined Axis on the duration of day and night
sections.content_md:
*   The duration of day and night is not equal at all places.
*   The time of the day at any place is determined by the height of the sun in the sky.
*   If the axis of the earth was vertical instead of inclined, places on earth would have the same temperature throughout the year.
*   If the earth did not revolve around the sun even then with its inclined axis there would be no seasons.

Because the axis is inclined, the duration of day and night differs at various latitudes:
*   **At the Equator**: Length of day = Length of night.
*   **On the Tropic of Cancer**: In summer, days are longer than nights.
*   **On the Arctic Circle**: In summer, there is continuous light for six months (Day of 24 hours near the North Pole).
*   **On the Tropic of Capricorn**: In its summer (Northern Hemisphere's winter), days are shorter than nights.
*   **On the Antarctic Circle**: In winter, there is continuous darkness (Night for 24 hours near the South Pole for six months).

[Image: Fig. 3.3. Inclined Axis]

sections.title: Effect of the Inclined Axis on Seasons
sections.content_md: The path of the earth around the sun is known as **elliptic**. The earth's axis is tilted at an angle of 66½° to the plane of the elliptic. As a result, during the earth's movement around the sun, the North Pole remains inclined towards the sun for part of the year while the South Pole is tilted away from it. For the remaining part of the year, the situation is reversed. This gives rise to the changing seasons and the varying lengths of day and night. If the earth's axis were perpendicular to the plane of orbit, there would be equal nights and days at all places, at all times of the year, and there would be no seasons.

sections.title: WHY WE DO NOT FEEL THE MOTIONS OF THE EARTH?
sections.content_md: The force of gravity keeps everything attached to the earth, keeping all objects at rest with reference to the motions of the earth. Based on this principle and Newton's First Law of Motion, scientists have proved that the earth rotates on its axis.

sections.title: REVOLUTION OF THE EARTH
sections.content_md:
The earth revolves round the sun in an elliptical orbit. This motion, together with rotation, makes the earth's environment complex.

[Image: Fig. 3.4. Revolution of the Earth]

sections.title: Characteristics of Revolution
sections.content_md:
*   The earth moves round the sun in an elliptical orbit at an average speed of **29.8 kilometres per second** or about 100,000 kilometres per hour.
*   The speed of revolution is not uniform. When the earth is closer to the sun, the gravitational pull makes it move faster.
*   The period taken for one complete round is 365 days, 5 hours, 48 minutes and 45.51 seconds, taken as **365 days and 6 hours**. One **Solar year** is 365 days.
*   The remaining 6 hours are adjusted every 4 years into one complete day added to February. A year with 29 days in February is a **leap year** (366 days).
*   The earth's axis is always inclined to its orbital plane at an angle of 66½°. The motion is from west to east, the same as rotation.

sections.title: Seasonal Changes
sections.content_md: The amount of heat a place receives depends on the angle at which the sun's rays reach it. Vertical sun rays concentrate heat on a small area, making it hot. Oblique rays spread the same heat over a larger area. The tilt of the earth's axis causes seasons. Revolution causes different seasons due to differences in the heating of the earth. It is an annual cycle, so seasons repeat year after year.

sections.title: Inclination of axis and seasonal changes
sections.content_md: Since the earth is tilted, the seasonal changes are not abrupt.

sections.title: Perihelion and Aphelion positions
sections.content_md:
The earth's orbit is elliptical, so the distance between the earth and sun varies.

*   **Perihelion**: The position when the earth is closest to the sun. The distance is **147.3 million km**. This occurs on or about **January 3rd** every year. It is winter in the Northern Hemisphere, but the comparative nearness helps make the Southern Hemisphere warm in summer.
*   **Aphelion**: The position when the earth is farthest from the sun. The distance is **152 million km**. This occurs on or about **July 4th**.

[Image: Fig. 3.5. Perihelion and Aphelion Positions]

sections.title: Creation of heat zones
sections.content_md:
The spherical shape of the earth and its movements cause differences in the angles at which sun's rays fall on the surface. This leads to the division of the world into three distinct heat or temperature zones.

[Image: Fig. 3.6. Important Parallels of Latitudes]

sections.title: The Torrid Zone
sections.content_md: This zone stretches between **23½° N and S latitudes**. It receives more or less vertical rays of the sun, experiencing a moderately warm climate throughout the year.

sections.title: The Temperate Zone
sections.content_md: Located between the Torrid and Frigid zones, from **23½° to 66½°** in both North and South hemispheres. The sun's rays fall obliquely, resulting in a moderate climate.

sections.title: The Frigid Zone
sections.content_md: This zone extends from **66½° to 90°** (the poles) in both hemispheres. The sun's rays fall extremely obliquely, leading to an extremely cold climate.

sections.title: SOLSTICES AND EQUINOXES
sections.content_md: The lighted part of the earth is called the **circle of illumination**. This circle moves with the apparent movement of the sun, so only half of the earth faces the sun at any given point of time.

sections.title: Solstice
sections.content_md:
*   **Solstice** refers to the time when the sun reaches its highest or lowest point in the sky at noon, resulting in the shortest and longest days of the year.
*   The word is derived from Latin 'Sol' (sun) and 'sistere' (to stand still).
*   It happens twice a year: on **June 21 (Summer Solstice)** and **December 22 (Winter Solstice)**.
*   **Summer Solstice (June 21)**: The North Pole is tilted towards the sun. The sun is overhead at the Tropic of Cancer. The Southern Hemisphere is tilted away and experiences winter.
*   **Winter Solstice (December 22)**: The Southern Hemisphere is tilted towards the sun, while the Northern Hemisphere is tilted away. It is summer in the Southern Hemisphere and winter in the Northern Hemisphere.

sections.title: Equinox
sections.content_md:
*   **Equinox** refers to the time when the sun crosses the plane of the earth's Equator, making night and day of equal length.
*   The word is derived from Latin 'aequus' (equal) and 'nox' (night).
*   It happens twice a year: around **March 21 (Spring or Vernal Equinox)** and **September 23 (Autumnal Equinox)**.
*   On these two days, the sun shines vertically over the Equator (at an angle of 90°), and days and nights are of equal length throughout the world.
*   On **March 21**, it is spring in the Northern Hemisphere and autumn in the Southern Hemisphere.
*   On **September 23**, it is autumn in the Northern Hemisphere and spring in the Southern Hemisphere.

sections.title: ANGLE OF INCIDENCE AND DURATION OF DAYLIGHT
sections.content_md:
The angle of incidence of the sun's rays and duration of daylight vary at different latitudes. The altitude or angle of incidence is measured in degrees and is calculated by subtracting the latitude from 90° (the maximum angle at the Equator).

As seen in Table 3.1, hours of daylight are always 12 hours at the Equator. They increase or decrease towards the Poles depending on the season. Seasonal contrasts are maximum at mid-latitudes.

[Image: Table 3.1. Angle of incidence of the sun's rays and duration of daylight]

sections.title: CYCLE OF SEASONS
sections.content_md: The Equinoxes and Solstices mark positions of the earth that help explain how seasons occur and are reversed in the Northern and Southern Hemispheres. When it is summer in one hemisphere, it is winter in the other. Variations in the altitude of the sun cause the duration of day and night to vary with the seasons. In general, there are four seasons: **spring, summer, autumn, and winter**, corresponding to the dates of the solstices and equinoxes.

sections.title: Position on 21st June
sections.content_md: This is the **summer solstice** in the Northern Hemisphere. The sun's rays fall vertically on the Tropic of Cancer. Daylight increases from 12 hours at the Equator to 24 hours at 66½° N. Beyond the Arctic Circle, regions experience 24 hours of daylight, a phenomenon termed **'midnight sun'**. Norway is called the land of the midnight sun. In the Southern Hemisphere, it is winter.

sections.title: Position on 23rd September
sections.content_md: On this day, the sun is vertically overhead at the Equator, and days and nights are equal. It is **autumn** in the Northern Hemisphere and **spring** in the Southern Hemisphere. The duration of sunlight is 12 hours everywhere on earth.

sections.title: Position on 22nd December
sections.content_md: This is the **winter solstice** for the Northern Hemisphere. The Southern Hemisphere is tilted towards the sun and experiences summer. Areas beyond the Antarctic Circle experience 24 hours of daylight. The South Polar region has continuous sunlight for many days. It is **summer** in the Southern Hemisphere and **winter** in the Northern Hemisphere.

sections.title: Position on 21st March
sections.content_md: The sun's rays again fall vertically over the Equator. All places on earth have equal days and nights. It is a repeat of the September 23rd position regarding day/night duration, but seasons are different. It is **spring** in the Northern Hemisphere and **autumn** in the Southern Hemisphere.

sections.title: TWILIGHT IN LOW AND HIGH LATITUDES
sections.content_md:
There are great seasonal contrasts moving from the Equator to the Poles. During sunrise and sunset, even when the sun is below the horizon, we experience diffused light, which is a reflection by clouds and dust particles.

*   **Dusk** or **Twilight**: The period of diffused light between sunset and complete darkness.
*   **Dawn**: The period of diffused light between sunrise and full daylight.

This phenomenon is experienced more in temperate regions. The duration of twilight is large beyond 50° latitude and can last for as much as seven weeks in polar regions.

Twilight continues as long as the sun is 18° below the horizon. Its duration is 1 hour and 12 minutes at the Equator and increases towards the Poles. At the poles, the duration is 50 days long during the 3 months of alternating day and night.

At the Equator, the period of refracted light is short as the sun rises and sets in a vertical path. In temperate latitudes, it is longer as the sun rises and sets in an oblique path. It is much longer at the poles, which is why the winter darkness there is only twilight.

[Image: Fig. 3.7. Twilight]
